screen1.title: You spotlighted an . . . Addax!
screen1.description:
While they may seem at home walking along the roads at Fossil Rim, addax are actually native to the Sahara Desert, and they have many adaptations to survive in the harsh climate.

For instance, check out their coat! Now think about what color you wear in different temperatures - lighter colors to help reflect the sun’s rays and darker colors to absorb heat. The addax “wardrobe” is the same. Its fur is lighter in the hot seasons and darker in the cold seasons.

screen2.title: You spotlighted another.... Addax!
screen2.description: If you have ever been to the beach, you know it can be difficult to walk in the sand without sinking. Addax have a solution! When they come up to your car, take a look at their feet! Their feet are flat and wide, and are perfect for distributing their weight while traveling across the desert. Just like snowshoes...but for sand!

screen3.title: Your 1st Addax Challenge
screen3.description: While addax at Fossil Rim have no problem finding water to drink, it’s a different story in the Sahara Desert.
screen3.question: True or False: Addax have the ability to survive without drinking water regularly.

screen4.title: Your 2nd Addax Challenge
screen4.description: We know water is an extremely scarce resource in the desert so it’s important to not waste it when you find it.
screen4.question: What interesting adaptation do addax have that helps them to conserve water?

screen5.title: Try Again!
screen5.description: The desert is an environment with very little rainfall throughout the year. Animals and plants that call this region home must get creative to find ways to survive without having regular access to water.

screen6.title: Actually, both are right!
screen6.description: It sounds crazy, but addax have been known to go without drinking water for long periods of time - and we mean looong! Humans can go without water for a maximum of three days but addax can go for months without drinking water. Most of their water comes from the desert plants they eat. While it’s not a lot, it’s just enough for these desert antelopes.

screen7.title: Actually, both are correct!
screen7.description: In order to conserve water, addax produce concentrated urine and dry feces in order to keep as much water as possible. Waste not, want not! Addax can also tolerate large body temperature changes (upwards of 11 degrees Fahrenheit) before using nasal panting to cool down.

screen8.title: Actually, both are correct!
screen8.description: Addax can tolerate large body temperature changes (upwards of 11 degrees Fahrenheit) and use nasal panting to cool themselves down. They also have the ability to concentrate their urine to keep as much water as possible and produce extremely dry feces. Life may be hard in the desert but it’s no sweat for addax!

screen1.title: You spotlighted a . . . Southern White Rhino!
screen1.description:
White rhinos? But they’re gray! Dutch explorers were describing the wide, square mouth when they named the larger species of African rhinos “wide rhino;” however, English speakers misheard “wide” as “white!”

Their large mouth is great for grazing grasses in the African savannah, or their favorite Fossil Rim hay. A rhino can eat over 70lbs of food per day. Can you imagine trying to eat that much food with our small mouths?

screen2.title: You spotlighted another.... Southern White Rhino!
screen2.description:
What’s that bristley, red thing in the rhino area? Rhino skin might look like impenetrable armor, but it’s actually quite sensitive. They can’t buy sunblock or insect repellent! Rhinos wallow in the mud daily, which moisturizes their skin while blocking sunburns and biting insects.

With so much surface area that could itch, if our rhinos need to scratch a hard-to-reach place, the red bristle pole makes for a scratching post!

screen3.title: Your 1st Southern White Rhino Challenge
screen3.description: Rhinos are famous for their horns, but they are also known for their size and the large hump on the back of their neck.
screen3.question: What is the purpose of a rhino’s hump?

answers.answer: Store Water During the Dry Season
Keep Their Head From Dragging On the Ground

screen4.title: Your 2nd Southern White Rhino Challenge
screen4.description: As you take a look at our white rhino crash, notice how they all have different sizes and shapes to their horns.
screen4.question: What sort of organic material is a rhino horn made from?

screen5.title: Try Again!
screen5.description: Many animals have different adaptations for times when water is hard to find. A hump made of fatty tissue is an excellent way to store water, and animals like camels use them very effectively. However, the rhino’s hump has a different purpose.

screen6.title: You’re right!
screen6.description:
Rhinos eat a lot of grasses and produce a lot of dung. This dung fertilizes the grasses, and Fossil Rim even uses it to create compost for our hay fields!

Rhinos are considered an umbrella species. This means that protecting rhinos protects suitable habitats for dozens of other species, just like an umbrella protects you from the rain.

Rhinos also help shape the landscape by helping to control the plant populations, allowing a wide variety of plants to grow in the African savanna.

screen7.title: You’re correct!
screen7.description: A white rhino’s hump is filled with muscle to hold up their head, which can weigh over 100 lbs! Similar to horses, white rhinos are considered grazers, meaning they eat primarily grasses on the ground. The dense muscle reaches all the way toward their shoulders to ensure their massive head is at the perfect angle for chomping grass. Combine the low angle with their wide mouth, and a white rhino is like a lawnmower!

screen8.title: You’re right!
screen8.description:
Rhinos help shape the landscape by helping to control the plant populations, allowing a wide variety of plants to grow in the African savanna.

Rhinos are considered an umbrella species. This means that protecting rhinos protects suitable habitats for dozens of other species, just like an umbrella protects you from the rain.

Rhinos also produce a lot of dung. This dung fertilizes the grasses, and Fossil Rim even uses it to create compost for our hay fields!

screen9.title: Not on rhinos!
screen9.description: Rhino horns grow from the skin. Elephant tusks and narwhal horns - those are specialized teeth. The horns on hooved animals like cows and antelope have bone that is connected right to the skull. You’ll have to find an alternative for rhinos.

screen11.title: Your 3rd White Rhino Challenge
screen11.description: For such a large animal, you’d imagine rhinos play a major role in their ecosystem.
screen11.question: Why are rhinos so important?

answers.screen_display_name: Question Three Correct Answer Two Screen

screen12.title: That’s right!
screen12.description:
Rhino horns are made from the protein keratin. Look at your fingernails, and you can see the fibers that make them up. You can find the same fibrous lines on a rhino horn because your fingernails and hair are also keratin!

Rhinos are often illegally poached due to the mistaken belief that their horn has medicinal properties. Luckily for rhinos, conservation efforts to protect them and deter poaching have their wild population at a healthy 18,000 rhinos. By applying similar measures we can hopefully help our remaining rhino species.

screen1.title: You spotlighted a . . . Cheetah!
screen1.description:
Count to 3! That’s how long it takes a cheetah to reach their top speed! Even with their incredible acceleration, cheetahs can only sprint for 300 yards, or three football fields, before tiring.

It takes a lot of energy to move that fast, so they have to be well rested before they hunt. When you drive past our cheetah facility, you might see them doing what cats do best: napping.

screen2.title: You spotlighted another . . . Cheetah!
screen2.description:
Fossil Rim has cheetahs in two different locations on property: on Cheetah Hill and in our Jim Jackson Intensive Management Area. We group our cheetahs just like they would be in the wild.

If you see a lone cheetah, don’t worry, it’s likely a female who prefers to be alone. If you see multiple cheetahs, it’s usually a group of males, called a coalition, or our favorite: a mom with cubs.

screen3.title: Your 1st Cheetah Challenge
screen3.description: We like to give our cheetahs as natural of a life as possible, so we have recreated a part of their environment in their enclosures.
screen3.question: Can you guess what it is?

screen4.title: Your 2nd Cheetah Challenge
screen4.question: Fossil Rim is known across the country for our successful Cheetah Program, but do you know what made our program so well-known?

screen5.title: Looks like you’re climbing up the wrong tree!
screen5.description: Unlike other cats, cheetah are not good climbers since their claws don't retract like most cat claws. Their function is similar to a football player’s cleats helping with traction when running at high speeds. That’s why we’re not worried about them climbing out of their habitat! Climbing with cleats for hands and feet is extremely difficult!

screen6.title: Puuuurfect!
screen6.description: Fossil Rim has been breeding cheetah successfully for over 30 years! We pioneered new techniques for breeding that are now used all over the country. We continue to research new ways to ensure the survival of this endangered species.

screen7.title: You spotted the correct answer!
screen7.description: In the wild, cheetah use hills and termite mounds for a higher vantage point to survey the area around them. You might see some of our cheetahs sitting on the mounds watching our other animals walk by or even taking a look at you in your car!

screen8.title: You really know your stuff . . . and so do we!
screen8.description:
Fossil Rim has been a part of a number of research projects involving cheetah, including the first ever successful in-vitro fertilization (IVF) of a cheetah!

These accomplishments ensure that we can continue to conserve and protect cheetahs. We’ve been breeding and working with cheetahs for the past 30 years, and we’re not slowing down now!

screen1.title: You spotlighted a . . . Wild Turkey!
screen1.description:
Woah, this is not the drab brown bird featured on Thanksgiving decor. Check out those colors! By flushing their head with blood, they saturate the featherless skin with color.

Even their brown isn’t bland! Turkey feathers use light to create vibrant colors - just like soap bubble change colors as light shines on it from different angles. A turkey’s feathers feature deep oranges and eye-catching blues to attract other turkeys.

screen2.title: You spotlighted another . . . Wild Turkey!
screen2.description:
Did that thing just fly? Today’s domestic turkeys have a chest bred for being on bread! Their wild cousins with reasonably sized chests are still able to flap their way into trees.

That’s likely how the turkeys you’re seeing arrived at Fossil Rim. Turkeys on property are wild ones that have cleared our fences and chosen to make Fossil Rim their home.

screen3.title: Your 1st Wild Turkey Challenge
screen3.description: Male turkeys are known as toms or gobblers, whereas females are known as hens. Take a look at the turkey you found.
screen3.question: Can you tell if it is a male or a female just by looking at it?

screen4.title: Your 2nd Wild Turkey Challenge
screen4.description: It’s easy to tell the gobblers from the hens if you catch the males showing off! The boys will display for the ladies, appearing to almost double in size while they fan out their beautiful tail.
screen4.question: How are male turkeys able to supersize so quickly?

screen5.title: You can do it!
screen5.description: Males tend to be almost black in color, while hens stay a dusty brown. Displaying in the sunshine brings out luminous colors from the boys’ black feathers. You can look for a turkey's 'beard'. Males will have a 'beard' of modified feathers they wear like a necktie. Sometimes a dominant female can have a 'beard,' so in this case it is best to listen for that iconic gobble. There’s a reason the females aren't called gobblers!

screen6.title: Correct!
screen6.description: Think of when you get goosebumps, and your hair stands on end. Male turkeys can control the same type of muscles just below their skin to have all their feathers stand straight up to make them look larger. At least they’re not full of hot air!

screen7.title: Try Again!
screen7.description: At first, they may all look the same to you, but looks aren’t all that deceiving once you have the basics of grey-brown females and darker males with flecks of color.

screen8.title: You’re full of hot air!
screen8.description: If turkeys had to take a gulp of air to puff out their chests, their displays would only last as long as their breath. They might even turn blue. While turkeys do have blood vessels under the thin skin on their head to show off blue and red coloration, that doesn’t explain how they change their size.

screen1.title: You spotlighted a . . . Giraffe!
screen1.description:
Keep looking up! Giraffe can grow up to 18ft tall but can reach even further than that. Their tongue is prehensile and acts like a hand to grab the leaves from the tallest trees.

Wondering how high they can go? Take a look at where the leaves start-or stop- in the pasture. This browse line shows how high our tower can reach!

screen2.title: You spotlighted another….Giraffe!
screen2.description: Their height advantage helps them reach leaves that others cannot, which results in more available food for the animals below. While feasting,they also act as sentries since they are able to see predators before anyone else.

screen3.title: Your 1st Giraffe Challenge:
screen3.description: Giraffes are the tallest land mammal, but with increased height comes increased challenges. One of the BIGGEST challenges is circulating their blood throughout their body.
screen3.question: How do giraffes get blood all the way up to their brains?

screen4.title: Your 2nd Giraffe Challenge
screen4.question: Do adult giraffe sleep standing up or lying down?

screen5.title: That's right!
screen5.description:
No hypertension drugs required. Giraffe need high blood pressure at the level of their heart to help the blood travel the almost 6 feet of neck separating the heart and brain. In fact, their blood pressure is over 2.5 times greater than ours!

By the way, baby giraffes aren't born with high blood pressure. It increases as their body size increases.

screen6.title: You're not asleep at the wheel!
screen6.description:
Both answers are correct. In the wild, adult giraffe are known for sleeping in short bursts while standing up. Requiring very little sleep per day - as little as thirty minutes average - they stay standing and alert for predators.

As you may see on your visit, the giraffe at Fossil Rim actually do lie down to sleep because they are not threatened by any predators. Studies have shown that giraffe that feel safe will actually go into a deep (REM) sleep laying down with their necks held high.

screen7.title: Not quite!
screen7.description:
A giraffe's heart has to do some pretty big things, so it makes sense that it's large. Although their heart is around 2 feet long and can weigh 25 lbs, it's actually in proportion to its overall body size.

In comparison, an adult human's heart is about the size of 2 fists.

screen8.title: Luckily, you didn't take this challenge lying down!
screen8.description:
Both answers are correct. For a long time, it was thought that adult giraffe only slept standing up. Research has shown that they will lie down with their legs tucked and necks held high if they feel like there is no threat, actually going into a deep REM sleep. We often see them lying down in their Fossil Rim pasture. It is like all of us that fall asleep in the chair while watching TV - fortunately, giraffe don't wake up with a neck ache!

Adult giraffe do have the ability to function with very little sleep. They most often fall asleep in short bursts while standing up.

screen1.title: You spotlighted a . . . Scimitar-Horned Oryx!
screen1.description: Did you know “oryx” means straight horn? Taking a look, it’s clear these guys bent the rules! Scimitar-horned oryx get their name because those horns look like a curved scimitar sword that you’d see in Aladdin or Lawrence of Arabia.

screen2.title: You spotlighted another . . . Scimitar-Horned Oryx!
screen2.description: By the 1970s, scimitar-horned oryx had been hunted to extinction in the wild and were only found in zoos. Fossil Rim has contributed research and animals to scimitar reintroductions and helped to bring back their wild population. Wave to any little ones you see because they could end up living in the deserts of Africa!

screen3.title: Your 1st Scimitar-Horned Oryx Challenge
screen3.description: The scimitar-horned oryx is native to the Sahara Desert, where daily temperatures can be 115℉ or more!
screen3.question: How does a scimitar deal with the extreme heat in the desert?

screen4.title: Your 2nd Scimitar-Horned Oryx Challenge
screen4.description: When you live in an extreme environment like scimitar-horned oryx, you have to work around harsh conditions.
screen4.question: What behavioral strategy do they take to manage the intense sunshine?

screen5.title: Not quite!
screen5.description: Remember, the scimitar live in the Sahara Desert, and water is extremely scarce. Try again!

screen6.title: You're right!
screen6.description: While it may seem counterintuitive . . . when the going gets hot, scimitar-horned oryx crank up the thermometer. Their internal body temperature can raise up to 116℉ before they begin sweating (a reminder - humans run a fever at over 100℉), allowing the oryx to conserve more water. While Scimitar can withstand such extreme temperatures, they’ll seek shade wherever they can find it.

screen9.title: If the sun is intense, play in the shade!
screen9.description:
Scimitar-horned oryx do most of their movement and feeding at night. The added benefit is that plants retain more moisture at night, meaning the scimitar get additional water in their diet, key for a desert animal.

Scimitar aren't the only animals that are well adapted to life in the desert. All three species of oryx at Fossil Rim (Scimitar- horned oryx, gemsbok, and arabian oryx) do very well in the harsh conditions.

screen10.title: Not quite!
screen10.description: While you would think having a long tail that you could swish would be the perfect air conditioner, scimitar-horned oryx don't need their tails to help them cool off. They use the tail, instead, to protect against biting insects such as flies and fleas. Try again!

screen1.title: You spotlighted a…..Sable Antelope!
screen1.description:
Look at the whole herd. Anyone stick out to you? You probably see some cute babies, a broken horn or two, but do you notice the extra curved horns and darker color of our bull male?

Sable bulls are born the same color as females, but grow almost black in color as they mature. This sexual dimorphism (di- two; -morph looks) makes it easy to pick out the male from the group of chestnut colored females and younglings.

screen2.title: You spotlighted another…..Sable Antelope!
screen2.description:
You may be asking, why can’t I feed these animals? Sable are one of few antelope species that will stand their ground and push back against threats. They are known for standing up to predators and protecting other members of their herd where other antelope flee.

Combining this push-back attitude with curving horns on both males and females, Fossil Rim has found that it’s best not to give Sable reasons to be unhappy with you (like if you’re trying to save your pellets for other species).

screen3.title: Your 1st Sable Antelope Challenge
screen3.description: Those are impressive horns you’re seeing on all sable antelope - both male and female - so you can imagine power struggles can be fierce. There is an entire herd hierarchy, and we know the youngest are on the bottom.
screen3.question: Who is on top, in charge of the sable herd?

screen4.title: Your 2nd Sable Antelope Challenge
screen4.description: Male or female, all members of the sable herd are responsible for protecting the group. With over 30 antelope in a herd
screen4.question: Male or female, all members of the sable herd are responsible for protecting the group. With over 30 antelope in a herd, how do they organize themselves to help protect their herd?

screen5.title: As the song says - who runs the world? Girls!
screen5.description:
Sable are unique amongst antelope species in that their herd is matriarchal. There is a head female and often a core group of supporting female leaders that help make decisions for the herd. The more assertive females are sometimes a darker shade of brown, likely because of increased testosterone.

There’s no shortage of testosterone in the black-coated male, who is still responsible for helping to protect the herd, but the females makes the decisions.

screen6.title: You circled the right answer!
screen6.description:
When faced with danger, adults encircle their young, horns out, creating an impenetrable wall. When the herd beds down in the evenings, sable concentrate their young at the center of the group, with adults laying around the outer edges.

Take a look at the herd again. What direction is each individual looking? Often even at rest, each antelope will face a different direction to ensure that nothing can sneak up on the herd.

screen7.title: Sorry, Mister!
screen7.description: If sable went by who looks like a bodyguard, males would be in charge with their bulky muscles and sweeping horns. But looks aren't everything! You’ll have to find a different leader for this herd!

screen8.title: Sorry, Mister!
screen8.description: Pick a different direction. While sable seem to have a uniform look and impeccable posture, moving in rows means all horns are facing one way, leaving the group susceptible from the rear. Find something safer!

screen1.title: You spotlighted a….White-Tailed Deer!
screen1.description: One of the most interesting features about this deer is found in its name - white-tailed. The tail’s white underside is used like a warning flag when it is alarmed. By flashing the white as it runs away, it signals to other deer that there is danger near. The tail also serves as a warning for the predator to give up its chase since white-tailed deer can run up to 30 MPH.

screen2.title: You spotlighted another . . . White-Tailed Deer!
screen2.description: Antlers are a feature on a white-tailed deer that draws admiration from both humans and other deer. Only the males grow antlers, which are used to impress the females and to fight with rival males. Luckily for the males, the antlers typically work like boxing gloves - taking most of the impact of the battle and keeping the rest of the deer from serious injury.

screen3.title: Your 1st White-Tailed Deer Challenge
screen3.description: Male white-tailed deer grow their antlers yearly during a 4-6 month process.
screen3.question: During which part of the year are the antlers growing?

screen4.title: Your 2nd White-Tailed Deer Challenge
screen4.description: All mothers deserve a break some times.
screen4.question: How do these deer mothers deal with their fawns when they want to do their own thing?

screen5.title: Not quite!
screen5.description: Fall is the time when male white-tailed deer are in rut, meaning their energy and focus is going toward attracting females and battling rivals. Scarce vegetation in winter doesn’t provide enough of the extra energy in a deer’s diet that is needed for antler growth. That would be like trying to build a house during a material shortage!

screen6.title: Argg! You’ve found it!
screen6.description:
We have plenty, thank you! With the eradication of large predators across much of the US, White-tailed deer are now overpopulated in many parts of the country.

Overpopulation has led to areas of overgrazing and a rise in deer diseases. This is where regulated hunting can be a conservation tool. Working in concert with science-based recommendations, regulated hunting can help manage a healthier population size for the deer and their habitat.

screen7.title: That’s right!
screen7.description: Just like a stock trader, White-tailed deer cash-in when the value is highest. The same months when their diet of plants are lush and jam-packed with nutrients, the deer will be eating as much as possible. At their peak growth rate, their antlers can grow nearly two inches a week! Antlers start growing from scratch in early spring, are fully grown by the fall, and drop by the end of winter.

screen8.title: You’re safe!
screen8.description:
White-tailed deer were already on the property when we became a Wildlife Center. Today you can compare the looks and behaviors of our native white-tailed to their cousins from across the globe, like European fallow deer and Indian axis deer.

White-tailed deer at Fossil Rim serve as a reminder that there is plenty we can do for our native species, too!

screen9.title: You found it!
screen9.description:
White-tailed deer “tuck” their young to hide them from predators. The fawn’s spotted camouflage keeps them well hidden in forests and tall grasses under speckled sunlight.

Have you ever heard the phrase. 'I could smell you from a mile away'? That won't happen to a hiding white-tailed fawn. Their moms clean them before leaving for the day so that predators won't find them.

screen10.title: Not quite!
screen10.description: While leaving your offspring with a herd might offer them safety in numbers, deer herds do not have the same type of social systems as we do. A deer mother may drop off her fawn with a group, but there is no promise that the group will care for the little one. Try again!

screen11.title: Your 3rd White-Tailed Deer Challenge
screen11.description: I thought Fossil Rim was all about exotic species.
screen11.question: Why do we see white-tailed deer at Fossil Rim?

screen1.title: You spotlighted a…..Roan Antelope!
screen1.description:
How far away is the roan herd from your car? If they are close, do they seem concerned with your presence? These may be one of the largest antelope in the world, but roan can be incredibly wary.

In the wild, staying alert to danger means staying alive. However, their idea of flight over fight has a limit! They will stand their ground against predators if need be.

screen2.title: You spotlighted another….Roan Antelope!
screen2.description: That's a beautiful color! Roan Antelope take their name from roan horses, who are described as being a solid color with grey or white speckles. When you see our herd in the sunlight, you'll notice the silver sheen to their rust-colored coats that will remind you of a newly washed car.

screen3.title: Your 1st Roan Antelope Challenge
screen3.description: Is that you, little Grogu? With those ears, you would think these antelope could be related to Yoda from Star Wars! Those enormous ears are a huge help for roan in their native African grassland habitat.
screen3.question: Why are big ears so helpful?

screen4.title: Your 2nd Roan Antelope Challenge
screen4.description: When it comes to colder weather at Fossil Rim, many guests wonder about our African and Indian species that are used to warmer climates. The majority manage on their own during Texas winter, but the Roan Antelope do have a special heated barn just for them.
screen4.question: What winter issue got them their own barn?

screen5.title: Where’d you hear that?
screen5.description: The “mask” on its face helps the Roan Antelope with camouflage and heat distribution, so it does play a significant role in its survival.

screen6.title: That’s right!
screen6.description: Just like us, Roan Antelope body heat is concentrated in their core. This leaves the rest - arms, legs, ears, and lips - sticking out in the cold. Those body parts freeze first, meaning that those enormous ears on the roan are highly susceptible to frostbite. This is an excellent example of how every species at Fossil Rim needs special consideration.

screen7.title: Cool, you got it!
screen7.description: By having such large ears that hold a lot of blood vessels, Roan Antelope are able to dissipate heat. As the blood passes beneath the thinner skin of their ears, the heat radiates out like the steam off a boiling pot. This helps keep them cool in the African sun.

screen8.title: Not quite!
screen8.description: With those long legs, it would be much harder for them to become stuck.

screen1.title: You spotlighted an….Arabian Oryx!
screen1.description:
Is it one horn or two? Arabian oryx are believed to be a source of the mythical unicorn fables. With its bright, white coat and horns that line up when viewed from the side, it’s not hard to imagine early explorers getting confused.

If you look closely you might see some of our resident unicorns: Arabian oryx with only one horn. Since horns are permanent and do not grow back, these oryx will only have one horn for the rest of their lives. While they might not be magical, they are cool to see!

screen2.title: You spotlighted another…Arabian Oryx!
screen2.description: Operation Oryx! In the deserts of the Arabian peninsula, Arabian oryx were hunted to near extinction. A tremendous effort was made to conserve the few individuals that remained. The result was one of the first worldwide cooperative conservation programs for an endangered species. Thanks to ongoing conservation efforts, the Arabian oryx was the first species in history to be reclassified as “vulnerable” after becoming “Extinct in the Wild”.

screen3.title: Your 1st Arabian Oryx Challenge
screen3.description: The International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN) classifies animals into different categories based on their population numbers and how close they are to being extinct.
screen3.question: how many IUCN classifications are there?

screen4.title: Your 2nd Arabian Oryx Challenge
screen4.question: With over 37,000 different species on the IUCN list, it can be difficult to prioritize them all. Thankfully classification makes it easy...or does it? True or False: Species that are classified as “Least Concern” are doing perfectly well and do not need any protection.

screen5.title: Almost!
screen5.description: There are actually 7 different IUCN classifications for animals: Least Concern, Near Threatened, Vulnerable, Endangered, Critically Endangered, Extinct in the Wild, and Extinct. The different levels help us know what species are at the highest risk and need the most protection.

screen6.title: That’s right!
screen6.description:
Just because an animal is doing well now, doesn’t mean we shouldn't pay close attention to them!

Some species, like the common wildebeest, are classified as 'Least Concern'. However, they are so important to the food chain that if they were to go extinct, it could have a major impact on the rest of the animals in Africa.

Also, just because a species is doing well now, doesn’t mean they might be doing the same in a couple of years. At Fossil Rim we work with a wide range of species of different classifications to conserve and protect the environment as a whole.

screen7.title: Correct!
screen7.description: There are 7 different IUCN classifications for animals. From lowest to highest they are: Least Concern, Near Threatened, Vulnerable, Endangered, Critically Endangered, Extinct in the Wild, and Extinct. The different levels help us know what species are at the highest risk and need the most protection.

screen9.title: Try Again!
screen9.description: While it does make sense that animals classified as “Least Concern” would not necessarily need protection, that is not the case.

screen1.title: You spotlighted an….Aoudad!
screen1.description:
What is the first thing you notice when you look at aoudad? Their impressive horns!

More than just a hood ornament, the horns of the aoudad are unique and work just like a football player’s helmet. On the inside, the horns are filled with air-chambered, sponge-like tissues that act like shock absorbers when males are butting heads and fighting for dominance.

screen2.title: You spotlighted another.... Aoudad!
screen2.description:
Take a look at aoudad eyes and you’ll notice something pretty unique. Their pupils are rectangular and horizontal which might seem strange but serves a really important purpose.

The pupils enhance their peripheral vision allowing them to keep an eye out for danger as they climb up and down the rocky cliffs.

screen3.title: Your 1st Aoudad Challenge
screen3.description: Aoudad are expert climbers, being able to make their way up and down the cliffs at Fossil Rim with relative ease.
screen3.question: What allows them to climb so well?

screen4.title: Your 2nd Aoudad Challenge
screen4.description: Aoudad may be nimble jumpers and climbers but when faced with a predator or a threat, they do something very different.
screen4.question: What is it?

screen5.title: Not quite!
screen5.description: While you would think that aoudad would be light and nimble with all that climbing, they are actually quite heavy. However, being short and stocky does have some advantages. Just like most gymnasts, aoudad have a lower center of gravity which helps them balance when climbing up a cliffside.

screen6.title: That’s right!
screen6.description: When threatened, the natural instinct of aoudad is to “freeze” and blend into the shrubs and rocks around them. Their tan coat and flowing fringe along their legs and neck can make them very difficult to see. But predators need to watch out when facing down an aoudad, they’re not afraid to butt heads!

screen7.title: Correct!
screen7.description: Aoudad hooves are perfect for climbing. Their hooves are shaped to allow them to be more upright on their feet, similar to you standing on your tiptoes. This allows them to easily traverse steep, rocky surfaces.

screen9.title: Try Again!
screen9.description: Aoudad are not the fastest, and their predators, leopards and caracals, are also excellent climbers.

screen1.title: You spotlighted an . . . Axis Deer!
screen1.description: When you spot an axis deer, take a look at the unique coat pattern. The rows of spots earn them the name chital in India, which means spotted. Sound familiar? Another spotted animal at Fossil Rim gets its name from the same Hindi word: the cheetah!

screen2.title: You spotlighted another.... Axis Deer!
screen2.description:
Soft like velvet or hard like a rock, you’ll find axis deer in all stages of antler growth! Thanks to the relatively stable climate in India, axis deer don’t have a set breeding season. This means that they don’t have set times to lose their antlers unlike the deer you will find in Texas that lose their antlers in winter.

How many different antler growth stages can you spot?

screen3.title: Your 1st Axis Deer Challenge
screen3.description: Antlers are the fastest growing bone in the world, and male deer produce new sets of antlers every year.
screen3.question: What can you tell about an individual deer by looking at its antlers?

screen4.title: Your 2nd Axis Deer Challenge
screen4.description: You might see our axis deer standing on their hind legs looking up into trees in the early mornings.
screen4.question: Why would our deer be doing this?

screen5.title: Close!
screen5.description: It is true that antlers get bigger as a deer gets older. Once they reach a certain point, however, it can be hard to tell the exact age of the individual. It would be like trying to tell a person’s age by their height. A person who is 6’ tall can either be 17 or 70.

screen6.title: Correct!
screen6.description:
Are you surprised? Axis deer have scent glands right below their eyes that they rub on trees, bushes, and grasses to let other males know who is in charge of the area. They will also mark their territory with urine just like dogs.

While they’re up there, axis deer will also grab a tasty treat. Unlike other deer, they are browsers and enjoy eating leaves that are covered in morning dew.

screen7.title: Correct!
screen7.description: When a deer has larger antlers, it usually means that the individual has access to more quality food and water. Better resources means that the deer is getting more nutrients, which results in larger antlers. Female deer will usually look for mates with larger antlers because it shows that they have strong genes to pass along to the next generation.

screen8.title: You got it!
screen8.description:
While we usually think of deer as grazers, eating grass and hay, axis deer are also browsers. They enjoy juicy leaves especially in the early morning when they are covered in dew. It’s a great way to get tasty leaves while also being a source of water.

But that’s not the only reason they’re up there! The axis deer are actually using scent glands below their eyes to mark their territory and letting other deer know who is in charge.

screen1.title: You spotlighted an . . . American Bison!
screen1.description: Bison or buffalo? The two terms are often used to describe the same wooly, brown animal, but they actually refer to entirely different species. “Buffalo” refers to the water buffalo or the cape buffalo. The confusion dates back to the 1600s when explorers saw them and assumed they were similar to animals they had seen in Africa. Don’t worry, we know buffalo is what most of us first learned to call it!

screen2.title: You spotlighted another.... American Bison!
screen2.description: American bison are considered an umbrella species. Not because they protect other animals from the rain, but because they directly influence the environment around them. Bison are the premier prairie protectors, responsible for keeping the prairie clear of shrubs and allowing for the growth of new plants. Try to imagine what Fossil Rim would look like if we still had bison roaming Texas!

screen3.title: Your 1st American Bison Challenge
screen3.description: You might see our bison rolling around in wallows, covering themselves with dust or mud. While playing in the mud is a great way to pass the time, bison have a purpose for getting dirty.
screen3.question: What is it?

answers.answer: Cool off on a hot day

screen4.title: Your 2nd Bison Challenge
screen4.question: Bison are considered ruminants, so you might see our bison standing in their pasture doing what?

screen5.title: Exactly!
screen5.description: Bison wallow for a number of reasons, one of which is to cool off. It can get really hot with all that thick fur, so a quick mud bath is the perfect way to cool down and not get overheated. You also might see our bison wading in their pond next to the county road, it’s one of their favorite places to be in the summer.

screen6.title: You’re right!
screen6.description:
Ruminants are animals that re-chew their food, or cud. Ruminants have four chambered stomachs specialized for breaking down the plant matter in a process known as ruminating.. It can be a long process, but it helps get all the nutrients out of the plants they eat.

There are other ruminants in the park! See if you can find other animals that chew their cud!

screen7.title: Correct!
screen7.description: Just like when we put on bug spray to stop mosquitoes from biting us, taking mud or dust baths helps to coat the bison’s thick fur and prevent annoying insects from bothering them. It also helps to brush out any parasites like lice or ticks so the bison can stay healthy!

screen8.title: Not quite!
screen8.description: While our bison are the stars of the Front Gate, the universe is a mystery to them. Instead of ruminating about philosophical questions, the bison are actually concentrating on something to do with digestion.

screen1.title: You spotlighted a . . . Blackbuck!
screen1.description: One of these things is not like the other! Blackbuck are considered sexually dimorphic which means that the male and female blackbuck have visibly different characteristics. Females are tan and white while males turn black as they mature. Can you find another way to tell males and females apart? Take a look at the spiraling horns on top of their heads!

screen2.title: You spotlighted another . . . Blackbuck!
screen2.description:
Why is he by himself? Blackbuck males are very territorial, so they divide the pasture into different areas, called leks, that are claimed by a dominant individual. Since they don’t like other males coming into their home, keep an eye out for sparring.

Don’t worry though! They are not trying to hurt each other, it’s just a way to figure out who's the boss.

screen3.title: Your 1st Blackbuck Challenge
screen3.description: Have you seen blackbuck before today? These animals are considered “texotic” which means they can be a pretty common sight throughout Texas - even though they are originally from India.
screen3.question: Why do blackbuck thrive in Texas?

screen4.title: Your 2nd Blackbuck Challenge
screen4.description: Blackbuck females often form a harem in a lek. While the females are free to go where they please, the male Blackbuck makes every attempt to keep them in his territory. Watch closely!
screen4.question: What are the strategies the male uses to keep the ladies interested?

screen5.title: You’re right!
screen5.description:
Texas and India share a pretty similar climate thanks to being on roughly the same latitude line. When you combine this with all the land in Texas, it means that we have perfect conditions for blackbuck to thrive!

We have a lot of blackbuck at Fossil Rim, see if you can count them all!

screen6.title: Correct!
screen6.description: When a male blackbuck is trying to get a female’s attention, he will throw his head back to look impressive and strut around with his tail up. This flexing and showing off sometimes has the desired effect, but sometimes the ladies are not interested in him at all and ‘swipe left’, ignoring him completely.

screen7.title: Correct!
screen7.description:
Texas is full of private ranches which give blackbuck plenty of room to roam since they do not like tight, enclosed spaces. When you combine this with the similar climate to their homeland, it means Texas has the perfect conditions for blackbuck to thrive!

When you drive through the pasture, take a note of where the blackbuck are located. They might have moved to a different spot when you come back!

screen8.title: Exactly!
screen8.description: When the females start to leave a territory, it is not uncommon for a male to resort to desperate measures like chasing her back into his lek. Try as he might, it’s up to the ladies to decide where they want to go. Plus, he can't follow her into another male's lek without a fight.

screen1.title: You spotlighted a . . . Mountain Bongo!
screen1.description:
Nice one! Mountain Bongo are one of the most elusive species at Fossil Rim. If they are out and about, it’s your lucky day! Bongo are considered crepuscular which means they are really active during dusk and dawn.

Most of the day they like to stick to the trees, hiding out from any potential threats until the sun goes down. Luckily, they don’t have to worry about predators at Fossil Rim, but they still retain that survival instinct of staying under cover until the coast is clear.

screen2.title: You spotlighted another . . . Mountain Bongo!
screen2.description: Mountain Bongo are classified as critically endangered due to hunting and habitat loss. There are thought to be more bongo in captivity than there are in the wild. Thankfully, we have a plan! Fossil Rim works with other institutions around the country in what is known as a species survival plan or SSP. With everyone working together, we can get these animals back to their homeland in the forests of Kenya.

screen3.title: Your 1st Mountain Bongo Challenge
screen3.description: Bongo are a unique looking animal and use their coloration to help hide in the trees.
screen3.question: But how does a reddish-brown coat with white stripes help them hide in the forest?

screen4.title: Your 2nd Mountain Bongo Challenge
screen4.description: Bongo have other ways to help them navigate the world during dusk and dawn.
screen4.question: What other adaptation do these crepuscular animals have?

screen5.title: Exactly!
screen5.description: If you imagine a dense forest, the light that comes through the trees is broken up by the branches and leaves, making a unique pattern - like sunlight coming through your blinds at home. The white stripes on the bongo help them blend in with the broken sunlight pattern, helping them stay hidden from any nearby predators.

screen6.title: Exactly!
screen6.description: We hear you loud and clear! Bongo ears are adapted for good hearing. You can try it for yourself! Cup your ears and listen to how the sound changes. Having larger ears funnels the sound and makes everything much louder which is perfect for listening for danger.

screen7.title: Correct!
screen7.description:
If you imagine a dense African forest, there are a lot of shadowy places where the sunlight doesn’t quite make it to the forest floor. A darker color allows bongo to blend into those darker places to make it harder for predators to see them.

Plus, when frightened, bongo stand very still, which makes them almost invisible.

screen8.title: Not quite!
screen8.description: While excellent vision might be really helpful at night, bongo are not known for their eyesight. Besides, in the leafy forest, your vision can often be obstructed by a tree or a branch.

screen1.title: You spotlighted a . . . Dama Gazelle!
screen1.description:
Good job! Our dama gazelle, also known as addra gazelle, can be hard to find in the Buffer Pasture because the majority of our herd is located behind the scenes.

These critically endangered animals need all the help they can get, so our females and little ones are in a nice quiet area away from the noise of the park. As our herd matures, we hope to see more and more of our dama playing in the Buffer Pasture!

screen2.title: You spotlighted another . . . Dama Gazelle!
screen2.description: Gazelle? Antelope? What’s the difference? The answer is simple: all gazelles are antelope, but not all antelope are gazelles. Just like the other antelope you’re seeing, dama gazelle have hoofed feet and a four-chambered stomach. What distinguishes gazelles is their smaller size: dama max out at 200 lbs where most antelope range 300-800 lbs.

screen3.title: Your 1st Dama Gazelle Challenge
screen3.description: Look at those legs! A dama's long legs help make them world’s tallest gazelle.
screen3.question: What other advantage do their long legs provide?

screen4.title: Your 2nd Dama Gazelle Challenge
screen4.description: Dama spend the wet season within the edge of the Sahara desert and retreat in the dry season to the surrounding Sahel grassland.
screen4.question: Without much to hide behind, what sort of behaviors have dama gazelle developed to deal with the chance encounters that happen out in the desert?

screen5.title: Try Again
screen5.description: What trees? This may be why giraffe have long legs, but not for this gazelle. Dama browse what shrubs and grasses they can find in the Sahara desert and surrounding Sahelian grasslands. Dama have the height to eat from what few trees are out there, but there are more easily accessible food sources that don’t require standing on their back legs.

screen6.title: I’m afraid you’re correct!
screen6.description: When it comes to fight or flight, dama are all flight, all the time. Dama gazelle are highly vigilant, on alert for any other creature they see. You may notice that our Fossil Rim gazelle give plenty of space between themselves and anyone else - your car and other animals. As soon as they feel an inkling of a threat, they use those long legs to carry them far away.

screen7.title: Correct!
screen7.description: Cheetahs aren’t Fossil Rim’s only speedy species! With their long legs and slender frame, the dama gazelle is built like a sprinter. They can reach a top speed over 50 miles per hour, which helps them escape predators. Unfortunately, dama can’t outrun motorized vehicles! The wild population has been over-hunted to where today they are considered critically endangered.

screen8.title: Not a great plan!
screen8.description: Jumping straight in the air as something approaches may get you away for a moment. When gravity kicks in, you’re left with the same scenario, only less time! Gazelle do occasionally jump straight into the air as an energetic release, called pronking, similar to how we hoop and holler when we’re overjoyed.

screen1.title: You spotlighted an . . .Emu!
screen1.description:
Bird is the Word! Emus are from a family of large birds called ratites. While these birds cannot fly, they have powerful legs that allow them to reach speeds of 35 miles per hour.

Keep an eye out for our other resident ratite: the ostrich. While they may look similar, emus are native to Australia and are shorter than their African cousins.

screen2.title: You spotlighted another . . .Emu!
screen2.description: The emu have a distinctive look which is a result of their unique feathers. Each shaft actually has two feathers on it which gives them a shaggy look. The extra fluff does have a purpose though - helping with regulating temperature. It also helps them to camouflage into the shrubs in the Outback. See if you can pick out our emu when they are lying down!

screen3.title: Your 1st Emu Challenge
screen3.description: Unlike other species at Fossil Rim, it can be difficult to tell male and female emu apart. However, if you know what to look for it can be really quite simple.
screen3.question: How do emu experts tell them apart?

screen4.title: Your 2nd Emu Challenge
screen4.description: When it comes to chicks, a male emu is an excellent parent and puts in work to create the nest for the female to lay eggs.
screen4.question: What else will a male emu do to help?

answers.answer: Sit on the eggs and keep them warm

screen5.title: Not quite!
screen5.description: Don’t be blue though, it was a good guess! The blue on their neck does serve an important role in emu communication. Their neck and the area beneath the eye will change colors, just like a mood ring, to signal a number of different things, including if they are ready to mate.

screen6.title: You’re correct!
screen6.description:
Those avocado shaped eggs are looked after by the male emu. Often he will go without food or water for days to make sure the eggs are warm and safe. Talk about a great dad!

Emus aren’t alone in their parental skills. Most species of ratites have the male sit and incubate the nest as well.

screen7.title: Grrr you got it!
screen7.description: While emu don’t growl, the males and females do make different noises! If you listen closely, females make a booming noise that sounds like a drum. The male, on the other hand, makes a loud grunting sound.

screen8.title: Right!
screen8.description: After sitting and incubating the nest, the male will raise the new emu chicks and defend them from threats. He is so protective that he will sometimes even defend the chicks from the mother!

screen1.title: You spotlighted a . . . Fallow Deer!
screen1.description:
Fallow deer are the most common deer species at Fossil Rim, so it is not surprising that they are also one of the most widely domesticated species of deer in the world.

They are found on every continent except Antarctica and have been used as a food source since the last Ice Age!

screen2.title: You spotlighted another . . . Fallow Deer!
screen2.description:
Oh! Deer! We know it can be confusing, but don't be fooled by the color variation of the fallow deer. They might all look different, but they are all a part of the same species. Fallow deer come in a variety of colors from tan and white to chocolate brown.

There are about 14 different color variations at Fossil Rim so see if you can find them all!

screen3.title: Your Fallow Deer Challenge
screen3.description: Fallow deer are well known for their unique coloration.
screen3.question: Fallow deer are well known for their unique coloration, but what else makes them stand out from other species of deer?

screen4.title: Noooooot Quite!!!
screen4.description: While fallow deer do have a unique mating call with sounds like burping, most deer species have a version of this The red deer at Fossil Rim, for example, will bugle just like elk to let females know they are ready to mate.

screen5.title: You’re right!
screen5.description: Fallow deer antlers are what's known as palmated, meaning they are large and flat like a palm. Fallow deer are one of three species in the world to have palmated antlers along with moose and caribou.

screen1.title: You spotlighted a . . .Gemsbok!
screen1.description:
Wow! Look at those horns! The horns of the gemsbok can grow up to 4 feet in length and serve as an impressive deterrent to any predators.

But what exactly is a horn? Horns have two parts: an inner bone structure and an outer casing made of keratin. The keratin acts like a phone case, keeping the inner bone safe from any damage.

screen2.title: You spotlighted another . . .Gemsbok!
screen2.description:
Gemsbok are sometimes called the horse of the desert, and it's very easy to see why. With those long faces and tails, they have a lot of horse-like features. Surprisingly, though, they are actually more related to cows and goats!

Gemsbok are ruminants, and just like cows, chew their cud to make sure they get all the nutrients they need. See if you can spot other ruminants in this pasture: sable antelope and addax!

screen3.title: Your 1st Gemsbok Challenge
screen3.description: This striking antelope is known for its dramatic facial markings which have been the inspiration for artwork throughout Africa. However, their signature look serves an actual purpose.
screen3.question: What do you think it is?

screen4.title: Your 2nd Gemsbok Challenge
screen4.description: The markings on the adult gemsbok are memorable. When babies are born, they are just tan with no markings at all.
screen4.question: Why would they look different from their parents?

screen5.title: It didn’t take you long to find the right answer!
screen5.description:
Most animals, humans included, rely heavily on eyesight to navigate the world. If their eyes are injured in a fight, it makes things extremely difficult! Since they can’t wear safety goggles, Gemsbok hide the location of their eyes within a thick black stripe.

The markings also help to make their horns look even longer and more impressive to tell predators: Don’t mess with me!

screen6.title: Right!
screen6.description:
Typically younger animals are more vulnerable to predators, so it’s helpful if the predators can’t find them at all. Baby gemsbok are born a dusty tan color so they can blend in with the desert sands around them. Even at Fossil Rim, the baby gemsbok can be hard to find!

Keep your eyes peeled - you might find them hiding under the trees or near a hay bale.

screen7.title: We knew you could see the answer right away!
screen7.description: Most animals, humans included, rely heavily on eyesight to navigate the world. If their eyes are injured in a fight, it makes things extremely difficult! Since they can’t wear safety goggles, gemsbok hide the location of their eyes within a thick black stripe.

screen8.title: Not quite!
screen8.description: Why don’t you chew on that some more. Most animals don’t change colors based on their diet, like your tongue when you eat a popsicle. Otherwise most of our animals would be green since they love munching on the grasses in the pastures!

screen1.title: You spotlighted a . . . Greater Kudu!
screen1.description:
Were you checking the treeline? Kudu are known for living in forest edges and thickets of the African plains, and this habitat defines their incredible camouflage!

Their white stripes align with the streaks of sunlight that make it through the canopy. Kudu legs look just like young tree trunks, helped by the fact that their fur is the color of tree bark. To top it off, their fringed mane and Gandalf - like beards replicate the look of leaves in the shadows.

screen2.title: You spotlighted another . . . Greater Kudu!
screen2.description:
Is that an antelope or a horse!? Kudu are enormous - our tallest antelope species at Fossil Rim, and one of the tallest antelope in the world! This allows them to act like junior giraffes and grab leaves off medium-sized trees.

Adding to their incredible height, male judu grow Texas-sized corkscrew horns that could stretch over 5 feet if you could flatten them out!

screen3.title: Your 1st Greater Kudu Challenge
screen3.description: Edge habitats are where one habitat meets another. Kudu live in edge habitats overlapping African savannas and African forests.
screen3.question: What’s the first strategy a kudu takes when sensing danger from their spot amongst the tree line?

screen4.title: Your 2nd Greater Kudu Challenge
screen4.description: There are two species of kudu, named for their comparative size: greater and lesser. Here at Fossil Rim, we have greater kudu - not surprising given their big horns and beards.
screen4.question: That being said,something that sticks out is that their ears seem large even for a kudu! What sort of function is provided by those massive ears?

screen5.title: Stop right there! You’re correct!
screen5.description:
At any sign of danger, kudu become a picture in time, striking a pose and hoping that their camouflage keeps them hidden.

If that doesn’t work, they will take off running into the depths of the forest. For males to do so, they must stick up their chins like they’re looking at the stars! This brings their horns to their shoulders so that they don’t get caught on branches. They have to run cross-eyed, but it gets them away from harm!

screen6.title: You heard it here first!
screen6.description:
Kudu have adjustable, satellite dish ears to help their hearing. This improved audio makes up for reduced light at dawn and dusk, when kudu are most active.

Similar to nocturnal referring to night-time creature or diurnal referring to day-time creature, animals like kudu, who come out with the shadows, are known as crepuscular.

screen7.title: Hold your horses!
screen7.description: Golf-cart sized antelope are rather noticeable when they’re moving. Doesn’t it seem like kudu has put a lot of effort into their camouflage? Kudu will take off running into the depths of the forest as a secondary strategy, but you’ll have to guess again on their first response to danger.

screen8.title: Try Again
screen8.description: Not a fan of this answer. While kudu ears are large, they aren’t flimsy enough to create a gust.

screen1.title: You spotlighted a . . . Nile Lechwe!
screen1.description: Antelope scuba diving? How would goggles work with the boys’ horns? Nile lechwe aren’t true divers, but unlike most antelope, they are swimmers! Lechwe venture further into the water than just about any other antelope. With flipper-like webbing between their toes and an oily double-coat like a wetsuit for keeping dry and warm, lechwe are well-suited for wading into the floodplains of northeast Africa.

screen2.title: You spotlighted another . . .Nile Lechwe!
screen2.description: Fossil Rim likes to keep our animals as wild as possible, including placing them in environments that are similar to their native habitats. Since the Nile lechwe thrive in the river lowlands of northeast Africa, we placed them in our Preserve Pasture where you’ll often find them walking the creeks or munching on the grasses of the valley. There’s only so many species that will tromp through swamps, so watch for our lechwe to keep their difference.

screen3.title: Your 1st Nile Lechwe Challenge
screen3.description: In order to survive in the wild, species have different strategies to access resources. Some animals are generalists, eating a variety of foods. Some animals specialize in what they eat, often tied to specific habitat conditions.
screen3.question: What strategy do Nile lechwe use?

screen4.title: Your 2nd Nile Lechwe Challenge
screen4.question: How do specialists deal with their environment changing around them?

screen5.title: Generally, no!
screen5.description: Similar to giraffes and their height, Nile lechwe’s swimming allows them to reach foods that other antelope can’t access! Like you may eat both tacos and pizza but have one you prefer, Nile lechwe have their preference, too! They eat both water-based plants and land-based plants, but tend to prefer the aquatic variety. Try another strategy!

screen6.title: That’s right!
screen6.description:
Specialists don't have the flexibility to handle change like other species, which can leave them out of luck when change is brought on quickly. This is why conserving animals in their naitve habitat is so important.

But there’s always backup! Fossil Rim is dedicated to breeding endangered species like Nile lechwe to ensure that we can enjoy the marvels of these species for years to come.

screen7.title: Right answers are your specialty!
screen7.description: Nile lechwe’s ability to swim opens the door to untapped resources. It’s like they found their own hole-in-the-wall diner! Instead of jostling with other antelope over the plants on land, lechwe can be confident that they always have a meal hidden and available in the water.

screen8.title: I’d wait before moving!
screen8.description:
Specialist diets lead species to be highly tied to an environment. Consider the Nile lechwe. If they wanted to leave their native range along the Nile River for swampier pastures, they would need to survive stretches of oceans, deserts, or dry grasslands bigger than their entire current range!

It’s like playing hopscotch, but the next square is hundreds of miles away. Better find another way

screen1.title: You spotlighted an . . . Ostrich!
screen1.description: Look out! Ostrich have the biggest eyes of any land animal. They use it, in combination with their height, to keep an eye out for predators. Sometimes ostrich will travel with other animals and can act as a lookout for danger. With their powerful eyes, any predators have to be very sneaky to get the jump on them.

screen2.title: You spotlighted another . . . Ostrich!
screen2.description:
That’s a big bird! Ostrich are the largest bird in the world and can easily reach heights between 7 and 9ft! With such a large bird, you would need an equally large egg. Their eggs can weigh up to 3 lbs which is more than 2 dozen chicken eggs!

You can check out some of the eggs our ostrich have laid by visiting the Nature Store or the Children’s Animal Center.

screen3.title: Your 1st Ostrich Challenge
screen3.description: While they might not be able to fly, ostrich sure can move! Their powerful legs allow them to reach top speeds of 45mph. Their legs are also useful for something else.
screen3.question: What do you think it is?

screen4.title: Your 2nd Ostrich Challenge
screen4.description: It’s eating what? At Fossil Rim, our ostrich love to eat pellets and grasses; however, there are other items they eat regularly.
screen4.question: It’s eating what? At Fossil Rim, our ostrich love to eat pellets and grasses; however, there are other items they eat regularly. What are they?

screen5.title: Correct!
screen5.description:
But we might need to dig deeper here...ostrich don’t just dig holes for no reason. The male ostrich will use its powerful legs and two claws like a shovel, digging out a space for the female to lay her eggs. The female will then adjust the eggs in the nest with her beak, which is where the myth of ostriches sticking their head in the sand started.

Of course, ostrich will also defend their nest with those same powerful legs to keep predators at bay.

screen6.title: Rock On! You're right!
screen6.description: Since they don't have teeth, ostrich, like chickens, have a gizzard that helps them grind up their food. The gizzard has specialized muscles that work with the swallowed pebbles and stones during the digestion process. These grinding stones wear down over time, just like the gears in a machine, and need to be replaced. Ostrich are constantly on the lookout for new objects for the gizzard, so make sure you keep everything inside your vehicle at all times!

screen7.title: You’re right!
screen7.description:
When threatened, an ostrich can use its powerful leg muscles and two claws to deliver a swift kick - just like a soccer player. This kick has enough force to cause serious injuries and make any predator think twice about approaching the ostrich.

Ostrich can also use their powerful eggs to dig holes for making nests.

screen8.title: Correct!
screen8.description: Ostriches are omnivores just like us! While we may not resort to eating bugs or lizards when food is scarce, the ostrich isn’t too picky about where or what they eat. They have even been known to eat small rodents and snakes. Just another reason to make sure you keep everything in your vehicle! You don’t want an ostrich making a meal of your phone!

screen1.title: You spotlighted a . . . European Red Deer!
screen1.description:
That looks familiar! You may look at our Europeen red deer and think they are American elk or wapiti. It’s easy to understand where the confusion comes from since they both have similar coats and antler shapes. Even scientists thought they might be the same species at one point!

We like to think of the elk as the red deer’s slightly larger American cousin.

screen2.title: You spotlighted another . . . European Red Deer!
screen2.description:
Our male red deer have the biggest antlers at Fossil Rim. Each year the males grow a new set that can reach up to 3 feet in length or larger. Imagine growing something that large on your head every year!

If you want to check out some of the antlers we have collected at Fossil Rim, visit the Nature Store or the Children’s Animals Center.

screen3.title: Your 1st European Red Deer Challenge
screen3.description: Helllooo Ladies! Male European red deer put on a fantastic display during the rut with the hopes of gaining as many females in their harem as possible.
screen3.question: What is one method that the deer use to get their attention?

screen4.title: Try Again!
screen4.description: While diamonds are a girl’s best friend, European red deer can’t afford such trinkets and have to DIY their presents. Most deer aren’t into crafting, so they have to settle for something else.

screen5.title: Yoooooou are right!
screen5.description:
In order to attract the ladies, male red deer will bugle just like elk. The call is loud and can be heard all over Fossil Rim, especially during the morning and evening. It calls the female deer to his harem and tells the other males to back off!

They will also put their best foot forward by adding extra special cologne that they make from their own urine. Hot Stuff!

screen1.title: You spotlighted the . . . Sandhill Crane!
screen1.description: You might hear the call of our sandhill crane when driving through the park. The distinctive sound, like a broken trumpet, can be heard up to a half a mile away! Like other birds, cranes use their distinctive call to communicate information to other cranes or to call out to potential mates. Take a listen!

screen2.title: You spotlighted the . . . Sandhill Crane, again!
screen2.description: Wait, wasn’t he in the other pasture? Our sandhill crane is fully flighted and moves between pastures frequently. You might see him in the Buffer Pasture enjoying some food pellets or in the Main Pasture near one of our watering holes. While he could technically leave Fossil Rim, he has decided to make our pastures his permanent home.

screen3.title: Your 1st Sandhill Crane Challenge
screen3.description: Sandhill cranes have one of the longest migrations of any bird in the United States, from Canada and Alaska all the way back to Mexico, a round trip of 14,000 miles!
screen3.question: But why would the cranes take such a strenuous journey?

screen4.title: Your 2nd Sandhill Crane Challenge
screen4.description: When sandhill cranes migrate, they are often seen flying high in the sky in a “V” shaped formation.
screen4.question: What is so special about this particular shape when flying long distances?

screen5.title: That’s correct!
screen5.description: We are fortunate that our food is easily accessible in stores, but many birds migrate to find better sources of food. As winter arrives, the availability of insects and other food sources drops dramatically, so the birds must travel south. Once spring rolls around they fly back north. It’s a lot of work, but it ensures that the birds don’t go hungry.

screen6.title: Perhaps this challenge was too easy!
screen6.description: The “v” shape formation helps the birds conserve energy. Birds are able to ride the updrafts and downdrafts from the bird in front of them, allowing them to glide more often and not get as tired. This is the same reason that squadrons of jets will fly in this shape as it helps to save fuel.

screen7.title: You’re right!
screen7.description: Many migratory bird species travel to the same nesting sites every year. These sites are known to have enough food and water for adults and be a safe place to raise chicks. For the sandhill crane, the perfect nesting site is worth the strenuous journey.

screen8.title: Right!
screen8.description:
Flying in a ‘v’ shape definitely helps with communication and coordination. Birds are in constant communication with each other while migrating and this formation helps to keep everyone together, especially when flying over long distances.

Also, a formation allows for the changing of the lead bird to drop to the back of the line when they are tired almost like switching drivers on a road trip!

screen1.title: You spotlighted a . . . Common Waterbuck!
screen1.description:
Did you spot the target? If waterbuck are facing away from you, it’s hard not to notice the ring around their rump. Young waterbuck recognize their mom’s ring like you could pick your parents by their silhouette.

It’s also thought that having matching rings on the rump and under their chin could confuse predators about which end is which when the waterbuck has its head down grazing.

screen2.title: You spotlighted another . . . Common Waterbuck!
screen2.description: If you were a realtor helping waterbuck find a new home, their first request would be 'by the water'. Like their name suggests, waterbuck are never found more than a day's walk from a water source. They are confident swimmers, which you can’t say for most antelope, but prefer to browse on all the plants that grow in the shallows.

screen3.title: Your 1st Common Waterbuck Challenge
screen3.description: Waterbuck are a great reminder not to touch our animals. Their hair is coated in an oil like grease that won’t come off!
screen3.question: Why is the primary reason they have this oil?

screen4.title: Your 2nd Common Waterbuck Challenge
screen4.description: Do you see the bull male with footlong, ringed horns that curve forward? He’s the only big boy, so he doesn’t always stick with the herd. All other waterbuck you see are females or young males who will not challenge him.
screen4.question: This herd makeup, where there is only one mature male, is what you’ll see for most of the antelope species at Fossil Rim. Why?

screen5.title: It’s not the main reason!
screen5.description: Yes, waterbuck oil can smell awful, especially on musky bull males. Plus, you have probably experienced that feeling where gross taste follows gross smell. However, lions and crocodiles will still eat waterbuck if nothing else is available. There’s a greater reason at play for waterbuck oil.

screen6.title: So wild!
screen6.description:
The “v” shape formation helps the birds conserve energy. Birds are able to ride the updrafts and downdrafts from the bird in front of them, allowing them to glide more often and not get as tired. This is the same reason that squadrons of jets wilIn Africa, female antelope live together with their young, called a harem. The males fight amongst themselves to see who gets to be the lone bull with the harem. Those that can’t secure a harem live together in what’s called a bachelor herd.

While we don’t want the fighting, Fossil Rim tries to replicate the wild conditions here at the park so that our species can have offspring just like they would in the wild. With additional spaces for single bulls in off-display parts of the park, Fossil Rim rotates bulls in and out of our herds to maintain healthy genetics within our population.l fly in this shape as it helps to save fuel.

screen7.title: Makes Them Waterproof
screen7.description: Your answer sticks, but water doesn’t! The slick oil on their coat has moisture wick right off, just like a rain jacket. Their coat also functions as a diving suit, with a downy layer of fur underneath their slick layer to help keep them warm when stepping through the water.

screen8.title: Try Again!
screen8.description: While some of you may have had this thought at some point in your life, it’s not the case with antelope. Fossil Rim has chosen to keep one bull with our herds. The juvenile (young) males that you see will keep growing and hopefully have a chance at leading their own herd one day. Try again!

screen1.title: You spotlighted a . . . Common Wildebeest!
screen1.description:
Great find! Wildebeest are well known for their incredible migration. Each year, nearly 1 million wildebeest trek across the African plains, following the rains and the grasses it grows.

This incredible journey takes them almost 1,800 miles! That’s like walking from South Padre Island at the southern tip of Texas, all the way to the US- Canadain border!

screen2.title: You spotlighted another . . . Common Wildebeest!
screen2.description: If you’ve seen a wildebeest before today, there’s a good chance they were in the jaws of a predator. Wildebeest are a major part of the diet for African predators like lions, leopards, hyenas, and crocodiles. So much so that wildebeest are considered a keystone species for the African savannas. Like the central stone that keeps an arch upright, if wildebeest were completely removed, the ecosystem would collapse.

screen3.title: Your 1st Common Wildebeest Challenge
screen3.description: What a look! Compared to other antelope, how would you describe a wildebeest's shape? Disproportionate? Unique? Wild(e)?
screen3.question: As unconventional as they seem, what ability does its shape give them?

screen4.title: Your 2nd Common Wildebeest Challenge
screen4.description: Where do we begin with that face? Both ladies and gents sport flowing beards. We can see that wildebeest give horses a run for their money when it comes to having the longest face.
screen4.question: Why would a wildebeest want such a long face?

screen5.title: Correct!
screen5.description: While their bulky front shoulders make their back legs look pitiful, a wildebeest’s concentrated chest muscles are great for running long distances. Wildebeest muscle tissue is roughly three times more efficient than muscle tissue of human athletes! This does give them a characteristic loping stride, but they can still reach a top speed of 40 mph.

screen6.title: I see you!
screen6.description:
Similar to horses, wildebeest primarily eat grasses. With eyes positioned at the top of their head, they can keep a lookout for danger even when their head is down.

If you see any wildebeest laying down, try to imagine tall grasses around them. Like a nosy neighbor peeking over a fence, wildebeest laying in grasses can keep most of their body hidden while still keeping their eyes on watch for danger.

screen7.title: That’s a leap!
screen7.description: Wildebeest have to cross water barriers during their migration, but that makes up only a small fraction of their journey. While they do possess explosive power to speed away from predators, they do so by sprinting rather than bounding. Take another look.

screen8.title: That stinks!
screen8.description: Wildebeest do have a great sense of smell that they use to detect impending rain and the resulting food. However, that doesn’t explain why their eyes would be so far from their nose and mouth. Try again!

screen1.title: You spotlighted a . . . Hartmann's Mountain Zebra!
screen1.description:
Yipes! Check out those stripes! Did you know that the stripes are actually a form of camouflage? We know what you’re thinking: what object is stripey enough for them to blend? The answer is: each other!

Those dazzling stripes create an optical illusion when zebra run together. It makes it hard for predators to pick out an individual, so the stripes help zebra stay safe together.

screen2.title: You spotlighted another . . . Hartmann's Mountain Zebra!
screen2.description:
It’s not always black and white! Hartmann’s mountain zebra have a number of different features that make them stand out from other zebra. If they come to visit your vehicle, take a look at their markings.

Every zebra has a unique set of stripes, just like a fingerprint. In addition, Hartmann’s mountain zebra have stripes that don’t cover the entire body, leaving a white underbelly. Also take a look at their face, the stripes there are actually chocolate brown in color!

screen3.title: Your 1st Hartmann's Mountain Zebra Challenge
screen3.question: Enough about stripes! While we know the stunning stripes are what everyone knows about zebra, do you know what other unique feature makes Hartmann's mountain zebra different from other zebra species?

screen4.title: Your 2nd Hartmann's Mountain Zebra Challenge
screen4.description: Woah there! You may notice our zebra chasing other zebra away from vehicles with some kicking.
screen4.question: What’s that about?

screen5.title: Correct!
screen5.description: Unlike the other varieties of zebra that are horse-like in shape, Hartmann's mountain zebra are shaped like donkeys! They have stubbier legs and a compacted shape for navigating mountainous terrain. Just like you must shorten your stride as you start up a hill, shorter limbs on a mountain zebra keep their balance centered beneath their body. Small, narrow hooves complete their climbing kit, allowing them to find stable gaps between shifting rocks.

screen6.title: You’re right!
screen6.description:
Zebra have an established hierarchy within the herd. This means that there are certain individuals at the top of the chain and some at the bottom. The kicking and biting helps to establish who is in charge of the herd. It's also the source of many of the scratches you might see on our zebra.

When a zebra tries to challenge the established order, like cutting in line for pellets, the other zebra will enforce the hierarchy by chasing off the offending individual.

screen7.title: Try Again!
screen7.description: An interesting theory for helping them to climb, but they have something else instead. They have other adaptations that help them navigate the rocky terrain. Check them out if they come close to your vehicle!

screen8.title: Close!
screen8.description: We all like our personal space, and when people get too close to us, we can be uncomfortable. Zebra are the same way but let each other know by flattening their ears or potentially nipping at the offending party. The aggressive chasing is caused by something else though.
